contentrichtext.text: '''James Andrew "Jim" Harrell, III''' (born 1974) served three terms as a [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] member of the [[North Carolina General Assembly]] representing the state's ninetieth [[North Carolina House of Representatives|House]] district, including constituents in [[Alleghany County, North Carolina|Alleghany]] and [[Surry County, North Carolina|Surry]] counties. Harrell is originally from [[Elkin, North Carolina]] and later moved to [[Roaring Gap, North Carolina|Roaring Gap]].<ref>[http://www.mtairynews.com/articles/2008/11/01/news/local_news/local03.txt Mount Airy News: Race for 90th House seat]</ref> As of 2011, Harrell is a [[lobbyist]], running his own firm, James A. Harrell, III and Associates, LLC, in Raleigh.<ref>[http://www.secretary.state.nc.us/lobbyists/Lobbyist.aspx?PId=9421515 NC Secretary of State lobbyist information]</ref> ==Early life and education== Harrell earned the [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] designation as a youth, like many members of his family.<ref>[http://www.elkintribune.com/view/full_story/6875484/article-Harrell-family-honored-during-Boy-Scouts-100th-celebration- Elkin Tribune]</ref> Harrell is a graduate of [[Hampden-Sydney College]] and the [[Emory University School of Law]]. While a law student, Harrell worked for the District Attorney's office in [[Fulton County, Georgia]]. He also served as a law clerk for [[North Carolina Supreme Court]] justice [[Franklin Freeman]].<ref>[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=10499 OurCampaigns.com]</ref> ==Political career== Harrell was elected to the House in 2002 and re-elected in 2004. He was elected to a third term on November 7, 2006 with over 60 percent of the vote.<ref>[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=288270 OurCampaigns.com: 2006]</ref> In 2008, he was narrowly defeated for re-election by Republican [[Sarah Stevens]].<ref>[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=402170 OurCampaigns.com: 2008]</ref> During his final term, the [[North Carolina General Assembly of 2007-2008|2007-2008 session]], Harrell was chairman of both the House committees on Ways and Means and on Pensions and Retirement.<ref>[http://www.ncleg.net/DocumentSites/HouseDocuments/2007-2008%20Session/2007%20Committee%20Assignments%20By%20Member.pdf NC General Assembly site]</ref> He served as chairman of the Environment and Natural Resources committee in his second term and of Judiciary Committee II in the second half of his first term. Harrell also chaired or co-chaired select committees on Economic Development and on the rural economy in 2006.<ref>[http://www.ncleg.net/DocumentSites/HouseDocuments/2005-2006%20Session/2005%20Committee%20Assignments%20by%20Member.pdf NC General Assembly site]</ref><ref>[http://www.ncleg.net/DocumentSites/HouseDocuments/2003-2004%20Session/2003%20Committee%20Assignments%20by%20Member.pdf NC General Assembly site]</ref> While serving in the legislature, Harrell founded a summer program to teach high school students about government and politics, named the [[James A. Harrell Jr.]] School of Government, after his father, a Surry County commissioner and candidate for the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] in 2004. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Harrell, James A.
